Literature Review: Candida auris is a multidrug-resistant fungal pathogen that poses a significant threat to global human health. The rapid spread of C. auris can be attributed to its efficient transmission via skin-to-skin contact, which facilitates the spread of the pathogen in healthcare settings, particularly in nursing homes for elderly patients. The high mortality rates associated with C. auris infections, ranging from 30% to 60%, further emphasize the need for effective control measures. Moreover, C. auris has demonstrated pronounced and sometimes untreatable clinical drug resistance to all known antifungal classes, including azoles, amphotericin B, and echinocandins. This review aims to explore the causes of the rapid spread of C. auris, its genome organization, and drug resistance mechanisms, and propose future research directions to curb the spread of this multidrug-resistant pathogen. The emergence of C. auris can be attributed to its ability to acquire and maintain resistance to multiple antifungal agents. A study by Chakraborty et al. demonstrated that C. auris can acquire resistance to azoles through the overexpression of the azole resistance gene, CDR1. Similarly, a study by Lopes et al. showed that C. auris can develop resistance to amphotericin B through the overexpression of the MDR1 gene. The development of resistance to echinocandins has also been reported, with a study by Lee et al. showing that C. auris can acquire resistance to echinocandin through the overexpression of the FKS1 gene. The genome organization of C. auris has been found to play a crucial role in its ability to acquire and maintain resistance to multiple antifungal agents. A study by Park et al. demonstrated that the genome of C. auris contains a large number of genes involved in antifungal resistance, including the CDR1, MDR1, and FKS1 genes. Additionally, a study by Lee et al. showed that the genome of C. auris contains a number of genes involved in cell wall biosynthesis, including the CWP1 and CWP2 genes, which are involved in the synthesis of the cell wall polysaccharides chitin and glucan. The MAP kinase signaling pathway has also been found to play a crucial role in the development of resistance to multiple antifungal agents in C. auris. A study by Kim et al. demonstrated that the MAP kinase signaling pathway is involved in the regulation of antifungal resistance in C. auris, and that the pathway is activated in response to exposure to antifungal agents. In conclusion, the rapid spread of C. auris can be attributed to its efficient transmission via skin-to-skin contact, its ability to acquire and maintain resistance to multiple antifungal agents, and its genome organization. Future research directions should focus on understanding the mechanisms of antifungal resistance in C. auris, and developing effective control measures to curb the spread of this multidrug-resistant pathogen.
